awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Capturing People's Expectations of Privacy with Mobile Apps by Combining Automated Scanning and Crowdsourcing Techniques
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of our work is to (a) capture people's expectations and surprises in using mobile apps in a scalable manner, and to (b) summarize these perceptions in a simple format to help people make better trust decisions. Our main idea is analyzing privacy in the form of people's expectations about what an app will and won't do, focusing on where an app breaks people's expectations. We are building an App Scanner that combines automated scanning techniques with crowdsourcing. Automated scanning captures the behavior of an app, while crowdsourcing is used to interpret how expected and acceptable this behavior is. This information is used as the basis for building a better privacy summary for apps. We have organized an interdisciplinary team with expertise in mobile computing, computer security, systems, and human-computer interaction.

Success in this work will include results in: (a) the design and implementation of an App Scanner that combines automated techniques with crowdsourcing techniques for analyzing and interpreting privacy-related behaviors of mobile apps; (b) a series of evaluations of this app scanner, showing effectiveness, accuracy, and scalability; (c) the design and evaluation of better privacy summaries, which prioritize and highlight the most unexpected behaviors of an app; and (d) demonstration of a new conceptualization of privacy, namely privacy as expectations. Success will also help end-users, corporate and government employees manage their privacy better than can be done today.

por.por_cntn:
The project has impacted technological advances to computer science, information science and engineering on how people can manage their privacy and security with mobile apps and similar systems. Further, the project has made substantial advance to science including: how to effectively crowdsource security and privacy studies on online platforms; designing, implementing and evaluating free-form gesture passwords; and how driving speed data can reveal driving routes and destinations.

On crowdsourcing security and privacy, we developed and evaluated several mobile apps. These apps explored users’ privacy and security concerns with mobile apps. For example, one of the apps highlighted app permission settings that the user has previously stated are concerning, and provided feedback on the use of secure and insecure network communication for each app. Our results show that access to address book information is by far the biggest privacy concern. We discovered that roughly 57% of the connections made by apps are insecure, and the destination of the majority of network traffic is North America, regardless of the location of the user. Our app provided unprecedented insight into apps’ communications behavior globally, indicating that the majority of apps currently use insecure network connections.

This project led to the invention of secure gestures for authentication. These free-form user-generated gesture passwords are a robust, usable and secure method of authentication, particularly suitable for mobile use. We developed several security metrics for gesture passwords, and were the first to analyze guessability of gesture passwords. We also found that simple instructions or composition policies change how users create gesture passwords, guiding users towards creating different passwords. We also conducted the first field study on memorability and usability of free-form gesture passwords. This study indicated that free-form gesture passwords are more resilient to multi-account interference than text passwords and that free-form gesture passwords provide better mobile usability than text passwords. We also developed a novel robust recognizer for secure gestures.

We have demonstrated a major attack on user location privacy that uses only speed data from driving traces and an initial starting location. This is an extremely hard problem that may seem simple in concept, but is difficult in execution for several reasons. For instance, if someone breaks and then accelerates they could have turned or they could have slowed down because the person in front of them was turning. This work was motivated by the fact that today, people have the opportunity to opt-in to usage-based automotive insurances for reduced premiums by allowing companies to monitor their driving behavior. Several companies claim to measure only speed data to preserve privacy; we show that this is not the case. With our elastic pathing algorithm, we show that drivers can be tracked by merely collecting their speed data and knowing their home location, which insurance companies do, with an accuracy that constitutes a substantial breach of privacy. To demonstrate the algorithm’s real-world applicability, we evaluated its performance with datasets from central New Jersey and Seattle, Washington, representing suburban and urban areas. Our latest version of elastic pathing algorithm is able to estimate destinations with error within 250 meters for 17% traces and within 500 meters for 24% traces in the New Jersey dataset (254 traces). For the Seattle dataset (691 traces), we similarly estimated destinations with error within 250 and 500 meters for 16% and 28% of the traces respectively.

The project contributed to the development of new formal roster classes at Rutgers University: one on mobile apps and one on security engineering. The results of the project were tightly integrated to these classes and included examples for 1) using crowdsourcing for user studies, 2) how to study and analyze existing user interface designs, and 3) how to integrate and design privacy with mobile apps. 

The project received remarkable media coverage including hundreds of broadcast news media, print press and online sites.

The project has provided research training, education and mentoring for several dozens of graduate and undergraduate students. A substantial number of these students belonged to demographics that were underrepresented in STEM disciplines. Several Master’s and PhD theses were published in the project. The project also included outreach to high school students and to industry.

The students involved, both undergraduate and graduate, have learned several important interdisciplinary skills during this project. They have learned about research software engineering best practices, data collection and analysis, ethics and procedures with studies involving human subjects, experimental study designs with human subjects, statistical analysis, generally on mobile security and privacy research, specifically on crowdsourcing for security and privacy and mobile authentication and privacy threats and leaks from mobile systems.

The project has made the source code publicly available for the major software prototypes and study applications generated in the project.
